Reduce: The target's size is halved in all dimensions, and its weight is reduced to one-eighth of normal. This reduction decreases its size by one category—from Medium to Small, for example. Until the spell ends, the target also has disadvantage on Strength checks and Strength saving throws. The target's weapons also shrink to match its new size. While these weapons are reduced, the target's attacks with them deal 1d4 less damage (this can't reduce the damage below 1).
Source: Player's Handbook p. 237

spell.name: Flock of Familiars
spell.text:
You temporarily summon three familiars—spirits that take animal forms of your choice. Each familiar uses the same rules and options for a familiar conjured by the find familiar spell. All the familiars conjured by this spell must be the same type of creature (celestials, fey, or fiends; your choice). If you already have a familiar conjured by the find familiar spell or similar means, then one fewer familiars are conjured by this spell.
Familiars summoned by this spell can telepathically communicate with you and share their visual or auditory senses while they are within 1 mile of you.
When you cast a spell with a range of touch, one of the familiars conjured by this spell can deliver the spell, as normal. However, you can cast a touch spell through only one familiar per turn.
At Higher Levels: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, you conjure an additional familiar for each slot level above 2nd.
Source: Lost Laboratory of Kwalish p. 57

spell.name: Minor Illusion
spell.text:
You create a sound or an image of an object within range that lasts for the duration. The illusion also ends if you dismiss it as an action or cast this spell again.
If you create a sound, its volume can range from a whisper to a scream. It can be your voice, someone else's voice, a lion's roar, a beating of drums, or any other sound you choose. The sound continues unabated throughout the duration, or you can make discrete sounds at different times before the spell ends.
If you create an image of an object—such as a chair, muddy footprints, or a small chest—it must be no larger than a 5-foot cube. The image can't create sound, light, smell, or any other sensory effect. Physical interaction with the image reveals it to be an illusion, because things can pass through it.
If a creature uses its action to examine the sound or image, the creature can determine that it is an illusion with a successful Intelligence (Investigation) check against your spell save DC. If a creature discerns the illusion for what it is, the illusion becomes faint to the creature.
Source: Player's Handbook p. 260

spell.name: Find Familiar
spell.materials: 10 gp worth of charcoal, incense, and herbs that must be consumed by fire in a brass brazier
spell.text:
You gain the service of a familiar, a spirit that takes an animal form you choose: bat, cat, crab, frog (toad), hawk, lizard, octopus, owl, poisonous snake, fish (quipper), rat, raven, sea horse, spider, or weasel. Appearing in an unoccupied space within range, the familiar has the statistics of the chosen form, though it is a celestial, fey, or fiend (your choice) instead of a beast.
Additional animal form choices may be available at the DM's discretion.
Your familiar acts independently of you, but it always obeys your commands. In combat, it rolls its own initiative and acts on its own turn. A familiar can't attack, but it can take other actions as normal.
When the familiar drops to 0 hit points, it disappears, leaving behind no physical form. It reappears after you cast this spell again.
While your familiar is within 100 feet of you, you can communicate with it telepathically. Additionally, as an action, you can see through your familiar's eyes and hear what it hears until the start of your next turn, gaining the benefits of any special senses that the familiar has. During this time, you are deafened and blinded with regard to your own senses.
As an action, you can temporarily dismiss your familiar. It disappears into a pocket dimension where it awaits your summons. Alternatively, you can dismiss it forever. As an action while it is temporarily dismissed, you can cause it to reappear in any unoccupied space within 30 feet of you.
You can't have more than one familiar at a time. If you cast this spell while you already have a familiar, you instead cause it to adopt a new form. Choose one of the forms from the above list. Your familiar transforms into the chosen creature.
Finally, when you cast a spell with a range of touch, your familiar can deliver the spell as if it had cast the spell. Your familiar must be within 100 feet of you, and it must use its reaction to deliver the spell when you cast it. If the spell requires an attack roll, you use your attack modifier for the roll.
Source: Player's Handbook p. 240

spell.name: Ray of Frost
spell.text:
A frigid beam of blue-white light streaks toward a creature within range. Make a ranged spell attack against the target. On a hit, it takes 1d8 cold damage, and its speed is reduced by 10 feet until the start of your next turn.
The spell's damage increases by 1d8 when you reach 5th level (2d8), 11th level (3d8), and 17th level (4d8).
Source: Player's Handbook p. 271

spell.name: Identify
spell.materials: a pearl worth at least 100 gp and an owl feather
spell.text:
You choose one object that you must touch throughout the casting of the spell. If it is a magic item or some other magic-imbued object, you learn its properties and how to use them, whether it requires attunement to use, and how many charges it has, if any. You learn whether any spells are affecting the item and what they are. If the item was created by a spell, you learn which spell created it.
If you instead touch a creature throughout the casting, you learn what spells, if any, are currently affecting it.
Source: Player's Handbook p. 252

spell.name: Chaos Bolt
spell.text:
You hurl an undulating, warbling mass of chaotic energy at one creature in range. Make a ranged spell attack against the target. On a hit, the target takes 2d8 + 1d6 damage. Choose one of the d8s. The number rolled on that die determines the attack's damage type, as shown below.
Chaos Bolt: d8 — Damage Type 1 — Acid 2 — Cold 3 — Fire 4 — Force 5 — Lightning 6 — Poison 7 — Psychic 8 — Thunder
If you roll the same number on both d8s, the chaotic energy leaps from the target to a different creature of your choice within 30 feet of it. Make a new attack roll against the new target, and make a new damage roll, which could cause the chaotic energy to leap again.
A creature can be targeted only once by each casting of this spell.
At Higher Levels: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, each target takes 1d6 extra damage of the type rolled for each slot level above 1st.
Source: Xanathar's Guide to Everything p. 151, Guildmasters' Guide to Ravnica

spell.name: Eldritch Blast
spell.text:
A beam of crackling energy streaks toward a creature within range. Make a ranged spell attack against the target. On a hit, the target takes 1d10 force damage.
The spell creates more than one beam when you reach higher levels: two beams at 5th level, three beams at 11th level, and four beams at 17th level. You can direct the beams at the same target or at different ones. Make a separate attack roll for each beam.
Source: Player's Handbook p. 237

spell.name: Fire Bolt
spell.text:
You hurl a mote of fire at a creature or object within range. Make a ranged spell attack against the target. On a hit, the target takes 1d10 fire damage. A flammable object hit by this spell ignites if it isn't being worn or carried.
This spell's damage increases by 1d10 when you reach 5th level (2d10), 11th level (3d10), and 17th level (4d10).
Source: Player's Handbook p. 242

spell.name: Shocking Grasp
spell.text:
Lightning springs from your hand to deliver a shock to a creature you try to touch. Make a melee spell attack against the target. You have advantage on the attack roll if the target is wearing armor made of metal. On a hit, the target takes 1d8 lightning damage, and it can't take reactions until the start of its next turn.
The spell's damage increases by 1d8 when you reach 5th level (2d8), 11th level (3d8), and 17th level (4d8).
Source: Player's Handbook p. 275

background.name: Mad Scientist (UA)
background.personality: There’s nothing I like more than a good mystery. My creations are my children, and I treat them as such. Explosions, while not ideal, are very, very cool. I'll act madder than I actually am to get out of things. I always think there's room for improvement.
background.ideals: Freedom. Discovery and invention should not be restricted. (Chaotic)
background.bonds: I sold my soul to the government for access to knowledge and materials. I hope to create great inventions and earn back my freedom. My studies are my life. I don't have anything else.
background.flaws: Most people scream and run when they see a sentient robot, hell-bend on the destruction of humanity. I stop and take notes on its mechanics. I'm always trying to upgrade my party's gear, even when they don't ask me to. (Or want me to.) My intellectual curiosity often supersedes my survival instincts.

feat.name: Description
feat.text:
Scientists are people that believe discovery and invention are vital to progress, and seek knowledge about the world in which they live. You are one of these people... but you take things a bit too far. To most people, your ideas are crazy: unnecessary at best, and reprehensible at worst. Because of this, you're shunned by your community, though whether your "madness" is legitimate or just a label slapped on you by people who don't understand is up to you.
You will want to discuss the reason(s) you left your home with your Dungeon Master. Did people harass you, or ignore you altogether? Were you run out of town for your bizarre experiments, or did you take your leave to try to find like-minded people? Are you searching for something obscure, or do you simply wish for freedom to study what and how you please?
• Skill Proficiencies: Choose two from Arcana, History, Investigation, Nature, Animal Handling, and Medicine. • Tool Proficiencies: Choose two from Alchemist's Supplies, Brewer's Supplies, Carpenter's Tools, Cook's Utensils, Mason's Tools, Smith's Tools, Tinker's Tools, Herbalism Kit, and Poisoner's Kit. • Equipment: A set of common clothes, two sets of tools you are proficient with, a book on your field of study, an abacus, a piece of chalk, and a pouch containing 10 gp
Source: Unearthed Arcana: Mad Scientist p. 1

feat.name: Field of Study
feat.text:
Every scientist has a specialty, even the "mad" ones. Choose a field of scientific study, or roll on the table below.
d6 — Field of Study 1 — Medicine 2 — Mechanical engineering 3 — Botany 4 — Zoology 5 — Chemistry 6 — Earth science

feat.name: Feature: Quick Study
feat.text: Others may criticize or mock your obsession, but your dedication has paid off. It takes you half the time it normally would to identify, repair, or glean information from an object, a specimen, or writings related to your field of study.

feat.name: Suggested Characteristics
feat.text:
Though they may have much in common, these are not the types of scholars that fill the halls of universities. They are radical free thinkers who are defined by ostracization. Greater society dismisses their ideas and goals as anything from foolish to evil, leaving them to work in their makeshift laboratories alone, for hours, days, or weeks at a time. They're obsessed. They're dedicated. Their ideas are strange -- but rest assured, no two are the same.
d8 — Personality Trait 1 — My creations are my children, and I treat them as such. 2 — I am dismissive of magic. 3 — I'm constantly covered in grime from my work and I am completely unbothered by this. 4 — Explosions, while not ideal, are very, very cool. 5 — I'll act madder than I actually am to get out of things. 6 — I'm lost in my thoughts more often than not. 7 — I always think there's room for improvement. 8 — I care about what people think much more than I let on.
d6 — Ideal 1 — Knowledge. I need to learn everything I can, even if others don't understand. (Neutral) 2 — Progress. I want the world to move forward, towards being a better place. (Good) 3 — Power. What I learn will help me rule over those who doubted me. (Evil) 4 — Freedom. Discovery and invention should not be restricted. (Chaotic) 5 — Method. There is a right way to do things. (Lawful) 6 — Legacy. I want to be remembered when I depart this plane. (Any)
d6 — Bond 1 — My work is of the utmost importance. I can't let how others see me get in the way. 2 — I'm working toward one specific discovery that will change everything. 3 — I will protect my journals at any cost. 4 — My experiments drove away someone I love. I hope to win them back by vindicating myself. 5 — I will return to the community that shunned me as a hero. 6 — My studies are my life. I don't have anything else.
d6 — Flaw 1 — I'm always trying to upgrade my party's gear, even when they don't ask me to. (Or want me to.) 2 — I don't have time for tact. 3 — Good luck trying to shut me up once I get talking about my studies. 4 — I am particularly territorial of my workspace: trespassers will be persecuted. 5 — My intellectual curiosity often supersedes my survival instincts. 6 — I'm very sensitive about my work and do not take criticism well.

feat.name: Gunner
feat.text:
You have a quick hand and keen eye when employing firearms, granting you the following benefits:
• Increase your Dexterity score by 1, to a maximum of 20.
• You gain proficiency with firearms. (see "Firearms" in the Dungeon Master's Guide)
• You ignore the loading property of firearms.
• Being within 5 feet of a hostile creature doesn't impose disadvantage on your ranged attack rolls.
Source: Tasha's Cauldron of Everything p. 80

item.name: Light Hammer
item.text:
Thrown: If a weapon has the thrown property, you can throw the weapon to make a ranged attack. If the weapon is a melee weapon, you use the same ability modifier for that attack roll and damage roll that you would use for a melee attack with the weapon. For example, if you throw a handaxe, you use your Strength, but if you throw a dagger, you can use either your Strength or your Dexterity, since the dagger has the finesse property.
Range: A weapon that can be used to make a ranged attack has a range shown in parentheses after the ammunition or thrown property. The range lists two numbers. The first is the weapon's normal range in feet, and the second indicates the weapon's maximum range. When attacking a target beyond normal range, you have disadvantage on the attack roll. You can't attack a target beyond the weapon's long range.
Light: A light weapon is small and easy to handle, making it ideal for use when fighting with two weapons.
Proficiency: simple, light hammer Source: Player's Handbook p. 149

item.name: Reinforced Labcoat
item.text:
Padded armor consists of quilted layers of cloth and batting.
The wearer has disadvantage on Stealth (Dexterity) checks.
Source: Player's Handbook p. 144

item.name: Smartphone
item.text:
A book might contain poetry, historical accounts, information pertaining to a particular field of lore, diagrams and notes on gnomish contraptions, or just about anything else that can be represented using text or pictures. A book of spells is a spellbook.
Source: Player's Handbook p. 151

item.name: M.E.G. 2000 …and 1
item.text:
The Multiple Element Gun 2001 is the latest upgrade in a series of brilliant inventions by Dr. Violetta Vermilion! Many improvements have been made since it's initial inception, but I'm sure I've worked out all the kinks and flaws!
...
This time...
An arcane focus is a special item designed to channel the power of arcane spells. A sorcerer, warlock, or wizard can use such an item as a spellcasting focus.
Source: Player's Handbook p. 151

item.name: Dagger
item.text:
Finesse: When making an attack with a finesse weapon, you use your choice of your Strength or Dexterity modifier for the attack and damage rolls. You must use the same modifier for both rolls.
Thrown: If a weapon has the thrown property, you can throw the weapon to make a ranged attack. If the weapon is a melee weapon, you use the same ability modifier for that attack roll and damage roll that you would use for a melee attack with the weapon. For example, if you throw a handaxe, you use your Strength, but if you throw a dagger, you can use either your Strength or your Dexterity, since the dagger has the finesse property.
Range: A weapon that can be used to make a ranged attack has a range shown in parentheses after the ammunition or thrown property. The range lists two numbers. The first is the weapon's normal range in feet, and the second indicates the weapon's maximum range. When attacking a target beyond normal range, you have disadvantage on the attack roll. You can't attack a target beyond the weapon's long range.
Light: A light weapon is small and easy to handle, making it ideal for use when fighting with two weapons.
Proficiency: simple, dagger Source: Player's Handbook p. 149

item.name: Dagger
item.text:
Finesse: When making an attack with a finesse weapon, you use your choice of your Strength or Dexterity modifier for the attack and damage rolls. You must use the same modifier for both rolls.
Thrown: If a weapon has the thrown property, you can throw the weapon to make a ranged attack. If the weapon is a melee weapon, you use the same ability modifier for that attack roll and damage roll that you would use for a melee attack with the weapon. For example, if you throw a handaxe, you use your Strength, but if you throw a dagger, you can use either your Strength or your Dexterity, since the dagger has the finesse property.
Range: A weapon that can be used to make a ranged attack has a range shown in parentheses after the ammunition or thrown property. The range lists two numbers. The first is the weapon's normal range in feet, and the second indicates the weapon's maximum range. When attacking a target beyond normal range, you have disadvantage on the attack roll. You can't attack a target beyond the weapon's long range.
Light: A light weapon is small and easy to handle, making it ideal for use when fighting with two weapons.
Proficiency: simple, dagger Source: Player's Handbook p. 149

item.name: Light Crossbow
item.text:
Ammunition: You can use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a ranged attack only if you have ammunition to fire from the weapon. Each time you attack with the weapon, you expend one piece of ammunition. Drawing the ammunition from a quiver, case, or other container is part of the attack (you need a free hand to load a one-handed weapon). At the end of the battle, you can recover half your expended ammunition by taking a minute to search the battlefield.
If you use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a melee attack, you treat the weapon as an improvised weapon (see "Improvised Weapons").
Range: A weapon that can be used to make a ranged attack has a range shown in parentheses after the ammunition or thrown property. The range lists two numbers. The first is the weapon's normal range in feet, and the second indicates the weapon's maximum range. When attacking a target beyond normal range, you have disadvantage on the attack roll. You can't attack a target beyond the weapon's long range.
Loading: Because of the time required to load this weapon, you can fire only one piece of ammunition from it when you use an action, bonus action, or reaction to fire it, regardless of the number of attacks you can normally make.
Two-Handed: This weapon requires two hands when you attack with it.
Proficiency: simple, light crossbow Source: Player's Handbook p. 149

item.name: Tablet
item.text:
A book might contain poetry, historical accounts, information pertaining to a particular field of lore, diagrams and notes on gnomish contraptions, or just about anything else that can be represented using text or pictures. A book of spells is a spellbook.
Source: Player's Handbook p. 151

item.name: The Chicago Manual of Thermodynamic Flux Induction Circuit Design
item.text:
"Thermodynamic flux induction circuit design is perhaps the most fascinating branch of practical electrical theory. Although limited to a low-pressure, sub-zero, nitrogen-free environment, the flux induction circuit can still be quite useful. The L.A.L.R. compiler is constructed by the following method: First develop a rigorous elective grammar. When induction elements have NP-completeness, the Krungie factor can be ignored."
After reading this book aloud in a most monotone voice for about a minute or so, you may find that creatures who listened to you speak have fallen asleep.
You can cast the spell sleep at will with a casting time of at least 1 minute, and a range of 15 feet centered on yourself. You will need to be able to physically open and read the contents of this tome aloud without interruptions or distractions for the full duration of its casting. For every successful minute of reading in this way, you can add a spell level to the spell in order to increase its effectiveness.
Source: Homebrew

item.name: Crossbow Bolt
item.text:
Ammunition: You can use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a ranged attack only if you have ammunition to fire from the weapon. Each time you attack with the weapon, you expend one piece of ammunition. Drawing the ammunition from a quiver, case, or other container is part of the attack (you need a free hand to load a one-handed weapon). At the end of the battle, you can recover half your expended ammunition by taking a minute to search the battlefield.
Source: Player's Handbook p. 150

item.name: Smith's Tools
item.text:
These special tools include the items needed to pursue a craft or trade. Proficiency with a set of artisan's tools lets you add your proficiency bonus to any ability checks you make using the tools in your craft. Each type of artisan's tools requires a separate proficiency.
Smith's tools allow you to work metal, heating it to alter its shape, repair damage, or work raw ingots into useful items.
Components: Smith's tools include hammers, tongs, charcoal, rags, and a whetstone.
Arcana and History: Your expertise lends you additional insight when examining metal objects, such as weapons.
Investigation: You can spot clues and make deductions that others might overlook when an investigation involves armor, weapons, or other metalwork.
Repair: With access to your tools and an open flame hot enough to make metal pliable, you can restore 10 hit points to a damaged metal object for each hour of work.
Source: Player's Handbook p. 154

item.name: Tinker's Tools
item.text:
These special tools include the items needed to pursue a craft or trade. Proficiency with a set of artisan's tools lets you add your proficiency bonus to any ability checks you make using the tools in your craft. Each type of artisan's tools requires a separate proficiency.
A set of tinker's tools is designed to enable you to repair many mundane objects. Though you can't manufacture much with tinker's tools, you can mend torn clothes, sharpen a worn sword, and patch a tattered suit of chain mail.
Components: Tinker's tools include a variety of hand tools, thread, needles, a whetstone, scraps of cloth and leather, and a small pot of glue.
History: You can determine the age and origin of objects, even if you have only a few pieces remaining from the original.
Investigation: When you inspect a damaged object, you gain knowledge of how it was damaged and how long ago.
Repair: You can restore 10 hit points to a damaged object for each hour of work. For any object, you need access to the raw materials required to repair it. For metal objects, you need access to an open flame hot enough to make the metal pliable.
Source: Player's Handbook p. 154

note.name: Backstory
note.text:
They told me I was mad… And in hindsight, I guess that turned out to be true. But how else was I going to be able to make my ideas into reality? Who knew that this little interest of mine would turn out to be soo expensive! And no billionaire turned up that would conveniently sponsor the private research of an eccentric inventor. So I turned to the only other alternative which had the necessary connections, and could afford to get me the materials I needed.
The Government.
For years I slaves away for them. Mostly by making great weapons of doom and destruction. But I cheated slightly by giving them bombs made out of pinball machine parts, so I could use the spare plutonium for my own research.
And I would have gotten away with it too, if it hadn’t been for those darn kids… I mean, assistants.

note.name: Virtues & Vices
note.text:
Virtues & Vices
Peak Virtue: Idealism - the quality of believing that things should be pursued to their most perfect form
Virtues: Curiosity - a state in which you want to learn more about something Ingenuity - the process of applying ideas to solve problems or meet challenges
Vices: Madness - rash or thoughtless behavior Voracity - unusually eager or enthusiastic about an activity

monster.label: Snowy
monster.name: Jetpack Penguin
monster.speed: walk 10 ft. swim 40 ft., fly 40 ft.
monster.text:
Penguins are arctic or costal flightless birds. They are social animals, gathering in large groups together. They are often curious about their surroundings.
Source: DNDBeyond, Homebrew.

trait.name: Flyby
trait.text: The jetpack penguin doesn't provoke opportunity attacks when it flies out of an enemy's reach.

trait.name: Hold Breath
trait.text: The jetpack penguin can hold its breath for 30 minutes.

trait.name: Familiar
trait.text: With the DM's permission, the Find Familiar spell can summon a jetpack penguin.

action.name: Peck
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +1 to hit, reach 5 ft., 1 target. Hit: 1 (1d4-1) piercing damage.
